client

Class Client

  • java.lang.Object
    • client.Client

  • public class Client
extends java.lang.Object
    The client will take the responsibility to inform the player about the commands send by the server. The client also contains a copy of the board and update this board according to the moves by all the players. Each player, no matter if the player is a computer player or a human player has its own client. This player is of type ClientPlayer. A client can only host one human player at a time.
    Author:
    Jonathan Juursema & Peter Wessels

        Parameters:

      • preparePlayer

        private void preparePlayer()
        Prepare the player object prior to a game. Contains shared code between challenges and regular game starts.

      • startGame

        public void startGame(java.lang.String[] args)
        Start a game. Should only be called after the hand has been filled, but could also be called before depending on server implementation.
        Parameters:
        args - The server arguments.

      • addToHand

        public void addToHand(java.lang.String[] tiles)
        Register a server add-to-hand command.
        Parameters:
        tiles - The server arguments.

      • addMove

        public void addMove(int tileInHand,
                    int x,
                    int y)
        Register a view's request to put a specified stone on a specified position.
        Parameters:
        tileInHand - The number of the tile in the hand. Note: it should be taken into account that these numbers change as stones are removed from the hand in the course of a turn.
        x - The x-coordinate.
        y - The y-coordinate.

      • setTurn

        public void setTurn(Turn turn)
        Bypass for requestSwap and addMove for the computer to use.
        Parameters:
        turn - The new turn.

      • requestSwap

        public void requestSwap(java.lang.String tile)
        The view requests to swap a tile from the hand.
        Parameters:
        tile - The number of the tile in the hand. Note: it should be taken into account that these numbers change as stones are removed from the hand in the course of a turn.

      • submitTurn

        public void submitTurn()
        Submit the turn to the server.

      • registerTurn

        public void registerTurn(java.lang.String[] args)
        Register an incoming turn from the server. The turn is checked with the Turn object, but we assume the turn contains no faults, because the server has checked it before. Or at least, should have.
        Parameters:
        args - The server arguments.

      • endGame

        public void endGame(java.lang.String[] args)
        We get an end-game from the server which we need to parse.
        Parameters:
        args - The server arguments.

      • chatFromClient

        public void chatFromClient(java.lang.String[] args)
        We receive a chat request from the view.
        Parameters:
        args - The chat, which is constructed of an array of strings, which should be joined with spaces, because we use spaces as our arguments separator. Confusing stuff. We know.

      • chatFromServer

        public void chatFromServer(java.lang.String[] args)
        We receive a chat from the server. This should be joined as well since the message could have contained the argument seperator from the protocol. Again, confusing stuff.
        Parameters:
        args - The server arguments.

      • invite

        public void invite(java.lang.String string)
        The view wants to send an invite to the server. We oblige, as always.
        Parameters:
        string - The nickname of the player-to-challenge.

      • undoRemoveFromHand

        public void undoRemoveFromHand()
        Undoes the remove-from-hand during a turn. Usefull in reverting a turn, or recovering from a wrong move.
